title: Right to Private Defence - Section 96 IPC
text: Nothing is an offence which is done in the exercise of the right of private defence.
simplified_summary: You have the right to defend yourself and others from harm without it being considered a crime.
real_life_example: If someone attacks you with a weapon, you can use force to protect yourself without being charged with assault.
punishment: No punishment - it is a legal right

title: Right to Defend Body and Property - Section 97 IPC
text: Every person has a right, subject to the restrictions contained in Section 99, to defend his own body, and the body of any other person, against any offence affecting the human body; and the property, whether movable or immovable, of himself or of any other person, against any act which is an offence falling under the definition of theft, robbery, mischief or criminal trespass.
simplified_summary: You can defend yourself, others, and property from criminal attacks including theft, robbery, and trespassing.
real_life_example: If someone tries to steal your car, you can use reasonable force to stop them and protect your property.
punishment: No punishment - it is a legal right

title: Limitations on Right of Private Defence - Section 99 IPC
text: There is no right of private defence in cases in which there is time to have recourse to the protection of the public authorities. The right of private defence in no case extends to the inflicting of more harm than it is necessary to inflict for the purpose of defence.
simplified_summary: You cannot claim self-defense if you had time to call police, or if you used more force than necessary.
real_life_example: If someone insults you and you have time to walk away or call police, you cannot attack them and claim self-defense.
punishment: May face criminal charges for excessive force

title: When Right of Private Defence Extends to Causing Death - Section 100 IPC
text: The right of private defence of the body extends, under the restrictions mentioned in the last preceding section, to the voluntary causing of death or of any other harm to the assailant, if the offence which occasions the exercise of the right be of any of the descriptions hereinafter enumerated: (1) Such an assault as may reasonably cause the apprehension that death will otherwise be the consequence of such assault; (2) Such an assault as may reasonably cause the apprehension that grievous hurt will otherwise be the consequence of such assault; (3) An assault with the intention of committing rape; (4) An assault with the intention of gratifying unnatural lust; (5) An assault with the intention of kidnapping or abducting; (6) An assault with the intention of wrongfully confining a person, under circumstances which may reasonably cause him to apprehend that he will be unable to have recourse to the public authorities for his release.
simplified_summary: You can use deadly force in self-defense when facing serious threats like murder, rape, kidnapping, or grievous hurt.
real_life_example: If someone attacks you with a knife intending to kill you, you can use deadly force to stop them and it won't be considered murder.
punishment: No punishment - justified self-defense

title: When Right of Private Defence of Body Extends to Causing Harm Other Than Death - Section 101 IPC
text: If the offence be not of any of the descriptions enumerated in the last preceding section, the right of private defence of the body does not extend to the voluntary causing of death to the assailant, but does extend, under the restrictions mentioned in Section 99, to the voluntary causing to the assailant of any harm other than death.
simplified_summary: For minor attacks, you can defend yourself but cannot cause death - only other harm like injury.
real_life_example: If someone punches you, you can punch back or restrain them, but you cannot kill them in response.
punishment: No punishment for reasonable defense

title: Commencement and Continuance of Right of Private Defence of Body - Section 102 IPC
text: The right of private defence of the body commences as soon as a reasonable apprehension of danger to the body arises from an attempt or threat to commit the offence, though the offence may not have been committed; and it continues as long as such apprehension of danger to the body continues.
simplified_summary: Your right to defend yourself starts when you reasonably fear danger and continues as long as the threat exists.
real_life_example: If someone threatens to kill you and reaches for a weapon, you can defend yourself immediately, even before they actually attack.
punishment: No punishment - justified defense

title: When Right of Private Defence of Property Extends to Causing Death - Section 103 IPC
text: The right of private defence of property extends, under the restrictions mentioned in Section 99, to the voluntary causing of death or of any other harm to the wrong-doer, if the offence, the committing of which, or the attempting to commit which, occasions the exercise of the right, be theft, mischief, or criminal trespass, of any of the descriptions hereinafter enumerated: (1) Robbery; (2) House-breaking by night; (3) Mischief by fire committed on any building, tent or vessel, which building, tent or vessel is used as a human dwelling, or as a place for the custody of property; (4) Theft, mischief, or house-trespass, under such circumstances as may reasonably cause apprehension that death or grievous hurt will be the consequence, if such right of private defence is not exercised.
simplified_summary: You can use deadly force to protect your property from serious crimes like robbery, house-breaking at night, or arson.
real_life_example: If someone breaks into your house at night to rob you, you can use deadly force to protect your home and family.
punishment: No punishment - justified property defense

title: When Right of Private Defence of Property Extends to Causing Harm Other Than Death - Section 104 IPC
text: If the offence, the committing of which, or the attempting to commit which, occasions the exercise of the right of private defence, be theft, mischief, or criminal trespass, not of any of the descriptions enumerated in the last preceding section, that right does not extend to the voluntary causing of death, but does extend, subject to the restrictions mentioned in Section 99, to the voluntary causing to the wrong-doer of any harm other than death.
simplified_summary: For minor property crimes, you can defend your property but cannot cause death - only other harm like injury.
real_life_example: If someone tries to steal your bicycle, you can stop them and restrain them, but you cannot kill them for it.
punishment: No punishment for reasonable property defense

title: Commencement and Continuance of Right of Private Defence of Property - Section 105 IPC
text: The right of private defence of property commences when a reasonable apprehension of danger to the property commences. The right of private defence of property against theft continues till the offender has effected his retreat with the property or either has effected his retreat with the property or has been deprived of it, or has secured its possession by a private person. The right of private defence of property against robbery continues as long as the offender is in the act of committing the robbery or of carrying away or attempting to carry away property which he has taken. The right of private defence of property against criminal trespass or mischief continues as long as the offender continues in the commission of criminal trespass or mischief.
simplified_summary: Your right to defend property starts when you fear danger to it and continues until the threat is over or property is recovered.
real_life_example: If someone steals your phone, you can chase them and try to get it back until they escape or you recover it.
punishment: No punishment - justified property defense

title: Right of Private Defence Against Deadly Assault When There is Risk of Harm to Innocent Person - Section 106 IPC
text: If in the exercise of the right of private defence against an assault which reasonably causes the apprehension of death, the defender be so situated that he cannot effectually exercise that right without risk of harm to an innocent person, his right of private defence extends to the running of that risk.
simplified_summary: If you're defending yourself from a deadly attack but might accidentally harm an innocent person, you can still defend yourself.
real_life_example: If someone attacks you with a knife in a crowded area, you can still defend yourself even if there's a risk of accidentally hitting a bystander.
punishment: No punishment - justified defense with risk

title: Culpable Homicide - Section 299 IPC
text: Whoever causes death by doing an act with the intention of causing death, or with the intention of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.
simplified_summary: Causing someone's death with intention or knowledge that it could cause death is culpable homicide (less serious than murder).
real_life_example: If you hit someone in a fight knowing they have a weak heart and they die, it's culpable homicide, not murder.
punishment: Imprisonment for life or up to 10 years and fine

title: Murder - Section 300 IPC
text: Except in the cases hereinafter excepted, culpable homicide is murder, if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or if the bodily injury intended to be inflicted is sufficient in the ordinary course of nature to cause death, or if the person committing the act knows that it is so imminently dangerous that it must in all probability cause death or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, and commits such act without any excuse for incurring the risk of causing death or such injury as aforesaid.
simplified_summary: Intentionally causing death or doing something so dangerous that death is almost certain is murder.
real_life_example: If you shoot someone in the head intending to kill them, or throw someone from a high building, it's murder.
punishment: Death penalty or imprisonment for life and fine

title: Punishment for Murder - Section 302 IPC
text: Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Murder is punished with either death penalty or life imprisonment, plus a fine.
real_life_example: If someone is convicted of murder, they will either be hanged or spend the rest of their life in prison.
punishment: Death penalty or imprisonment for life and fine

title: Punishment for Culpable Homicide Not Amounting to Murder - Section 304 IPC
text: Whoever commits culpable homicide not amounting to murder shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine, if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death; or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, or with fine, or with both, if the act is done with the knowledge that it is likely to cause death, but without any intention to cause death, or to cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death.
simplified_summary: Culpable homicide (less serious than murder) is punished with up to life imprisonment or 10 years, depending on intention.
real_life_example: If you cause someone's death without intending to kill them, you might get 10 years in prison instead of life.
punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine

title: Attempt to Murder - Section 307 IPC
text: Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge and under such circumstances that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of murder, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; and if hurt is caused to any person by such act, the offender shall be liable either to imprisonment for life, or to such punishment as is hereinbefore mentioned.
simplified_summary: Trying to kill someone but failing is attempt to murder, punished with up to 10 years or life if injury is caused.
real_life_example: If you shoot at someone intending to kill them but miss, you can still be charged with attempt to murder.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine, or life if injury caused

title: Attempt to Commit Culpable Homicide - Section 308 IPC
text: Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge and under such circumstances that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of culpable homicide not amounting to murder, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both; and if hurt is caused to any person by such act, the offender shall be liable to imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or shall be liable to fine, or to both.
simplified_summary: Trying to cause death without murderous intent is attempt to culpable homicide, punished with up to 3-7 years.
real_life_example: If you hit someone knowing they might die but not intending to kill them, it's attempt to culpable homicide.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine, or up to 7 years if injury caused

title: Attempt to Commit Suicide - Section 309 IPC
text: Whoever attempts to commit suicide and does any act towards the commission of such offence, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Attempting suicide is a crime punishable with up to 1 year in prison or fine (though rarely enforced).
real_life_example: If someone tries to kill themselves and fails, they can technically be charged with a crime, though this is rarely done.
punishment: Up to 1 year simple imprisonment or fine

title: Thug - Section 310 IPC
text: Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall have been habitually associated with any other or others for the purpose of committing robbery or child-stealing by means of or accompanied by murder, is a thug.
simplified_summary: A thug is someone who habitually commits robbery or child-stealing by murder as part of a group.
real_life_example: Members of organized crime groups who regularly rob and kill people are considered thugs.
punishment: Imprisonment for life and fine

title: Punishment for Thug - Section 311 IPC
text: Whoever is a thug, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Being a thug is punished with life imprisonment and fine.
real_life_example: If someone is convicted of being a thug, they will spend the rest of their life in prison.
punishment: Imprisonment for life and fine

title: Causing Miscarriage - Section 312 IPC
text: Whoever voluntarily causes a woman with child to miscarry, shall, if such miscarriage be not caused in good faith for the purpose of saving the life of the woman, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both; and, if the woman be quick with child, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Causing abortion is illegal unless done to save the woman's life, punished with up to 3-7 years in prison.
real_life_example: If someone forces a pregnant woman to have an abortion against her will, they can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine, or up to 7 years if woman is quick with child

title: Causing Miscarriage Without Woman's Consent - Section 313 IPC
text: Whoever commits the offence defined in the last preceding section without the consent of the woman, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Forcing abortion without the woman's consent is punished with up to life imprisonment.
real_life_example: If someone forces a woman to have an abortion against her will, they can be jailed for life.
punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine

title: Death Caused by Act Done with Intent to Cause Miscarriage - Section 314 IPC
text: Whoever, with intent to cause the miscarriage of a woman with child, does any act which causes the death of such woman, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; and if the act is done without the consent of the woman, shall be punished either with imprisonment for life, or with the punishment above mentioned.
simplified_summary: If someone causes a woman's death while trying to cause abortion, they can be jailed for up to 10 years or life.
real_life_example: If someone performs an unsafe abortion that kills the woman, they can be charged with causing death and jailed for life.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine, or life if without consent

title: Act Done with Intent to Prevent Child Being Born Alive or to Cause It to Die After Birth - Section 315 IPC
text: Whoever before the birth of any child does any act with the intention of preventing that child from being born alive or causing it to die after its birth, and does by such act prevent that child from being born alive, or causes it to die after its birth, shall, if such act be not caused in good faith for the purpose of saving the life of the mother, be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Intentionally preventing a child from being born alive or causing it to die after birth is illegal unless to save the mother's life.
real_life_example: If someone intentionally causes a baby to die during birth or right after, they can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Causing Death of Quick Unborn Child by Act Amounting to Culpable Homicide - Section 316 IPC
text: Whoever does any act under such circumstances, that if he thereby caused death he would be guilty of culpable homicide, and does by such act cause the death of a quick unborn child, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Causing the death of an unborn child (quick with child) through actions that would be culpable homicide is illegal.
real_life_example: If someone attacks a pregnant woman and causes the death of her unborn child, they can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Exposure and Abandonment of Child Under Twelve Years by Parent or Person Having Care of It - Section 317 IPC
text: Whoever being the father or mother of a child under the age of twelve years, or having the care of such child, shall expose or leave such child in any place with the intention of wholly abandoning such child, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Abandoning a child under 12 years old is illegal and punished with up to 7 years in prison.
real_life_example: If parents leave their 5-year-old child alone in a public place intending to abandon them, they can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Concealment of Birth by Secret Disposal of Dead Body - Section 318 IPC
text: Whoever, by secretly burying or otherwise disposing of the dead body of a child, whether such child died before or after or during its birth, intentionally conceals or endeavours to conceal the birth of such child, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Secretly disposing of a dead child's body to hide the birth is illegal and punished with up to 2 years in prison.
real_life_example: If someone secretly buries a stillborn baby to hide the pregnancy, they can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Hurt - Section 319 IPC
text: Whoever causes bodily pain, disease or infirmity to any person is said to cause hurt.
simplified_summary: Causing physical pain, disease, or weakness to someone is called hurt.
real_life_example: If you punch someone and they feel pain, you have caused hurt to them.
punishment: Depends on type of hurt caused

title: Grievous Hurt - Section 320 IPC
text: The following kinds of hurt only are designated as 'grievous': (1) Emasculation; (2) Permanent privation of the sight of either eye; (3) Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear; (4) Privation of any member or joint of the body; (5) Destruction or permanent impairing of the powers of any member or joint of the body; (6) Permanent disfiguration of the head or face; (7) Fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth; (8) Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer, during the space of twenty days, to be unable to follow his ordinary pursuits.
simplified_summary: Grievous hurt includes serious injuries like losing an eye, breaking bones, permanent disfigurement, or injuries that endanger life.
real_life_example: If you hit someone so hard that they lose an eye or break their arm, it's grievous hurt.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Voluntarily Causing Hurt - Section 321 IPC
text: Whoever does any act with the intention of thereby causing hurt to any person, or with the knowledge that he is likely thereby to cause hurt to any person, and does thereby cause hurt to any person, is said 'voluntarily to cause hurt'.
simplified_summary: Intentionally or knowingly causing hurt to someone is called voluntarily causing hurt.
real_life_example: If you intentionally hit someone knowing it will hurt them, you have voluntarily caused hurt.
punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment and fine

title: Voluntarily Causing Grievous Hurt - Section 322 IPC
text: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt, if the hurt which he intends to cause or knows himself to be likely to cause is grievous hurt, and if the hurt which he causes is grievous hurt, is said 'voluntarily to cause grievous hurt'.
simplified_summary: Intentionally or knowingly causing grievous hurt (serious injury) to someone is called voluntarily causing grievous hurt.
real_life_example: If you intentionally hit someone hard enough to break their bone, you have voluntarily caused grievous hurt.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Voluntarily Causing Hurt - Section 323 IPC
text: Whoever, except in the case provided for by Section 334, voluntarily causes hurt, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: Voluntarily causing hurt is punished with up to 1 year in prison or fine of up to 1000 rupees.
real_life_example: If you punch someone and cause them pain, you can be jailed for up to 1 year or fined 1000 rupees.
punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment and fine up to 1000 rupees

title: Voluntarily Causing Hurt by Dangerous Weapons or Means - Section 324 IPC
text: Whoever, except in the case provided for by Section 334, voluntarily causes hurt by means of any instrument for shooting, stabbing or cutting, or any instrument which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, or by means of fire or any heated substance, or by means of any poison or any corrosive substance, or by means of any explosive substance, or by means of any substance which it is deleterious to the human body to inhale, to swallow, or to receive into the blood, or by means of any animal, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Causing hurt with dangerous weapons like knives, guns, fire, poison, or animals is punished more severely - up to 3 years in prison.
real_life_example: If you cut someone with a knife or burn them with fire, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Voluntarily Causing Grievous Hurt - Section 325 IPC
text: Whoever, except in the case provided for by Section 335, voluntarily causes grievous hurt, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Voluntarily causing grievous hurt (serious injury) is punished with up to 7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you break someone's arm or cause them to lose an eye, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Voluntarily Causing Grievous Hurt by Dangerous Weapons or Means - Section 326 IPC
text: Whoever, except in the case provided for by Section 335, voluntarily causes grievous hurt by means of any instrument for shooting, stabbing or cutting, or any instrument which, used as a weapon of offence, is likely to cause death, or by means of fire or any heated substance, or by means of any poison or any corrosive substance, or by means of any explosive substance, or by means of any substance which it is deleterious to the human body to inhale, to swallow, or to receive into the blood, or by means of any animal, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Causing grievous hurt with dangerous weapons like knives, guns, fire, or poison is punished with up to 10 years in prison.
real_life_example: If you cut someone so badly with a knife that they lose a limb, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Voluntarily Causing Hurt to Extort Property or to Constrain to an Illegal Act - Section 327 IPC
text: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt, for the purpose of extorting from the sufferer or from any person interested in the sufferer any property or valuable security, or of constraining the sufferer or any person interested in the sufferer to do anything which is illegal or which may facilitate the commission of an offence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Causing hurt to extort money or force someone to do something illegal is punished with up to 10 years in prison.
real_life_example: If you beat someone to force them to give you money or commit a crime, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Voluntarily Causing Hurt by Means of Poison - Section 328 IPC
text: Whoever administers to or causes to be taken by any person any poison or any stupefying, intoxicating or unwholesome drug, or other thing with intent to cause hurt to such person, or with intent to commit or to facilitate the commission of an offence or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby cause hurt, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Giving someone poison or drugs to hurt them or commit a crime is punished with up to 10 years in prison.
real_life_example: If you put poison in someone's food to hurt them or make them unconscious, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Voluntarily Causing Grievous Hurt by Means of Poison - Section 329 IPC
text: Whoever administers to or causes to be taken by any person any poison or any stupefying, intoxicating or unwholesome drug, or other thing with intent to cause grievous hurt to such person, or with intent to commit or to facilitate the commission of an offence or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby cause grievous hurt, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Giving someone poison or drugs to cause serious injury is punished with up to 10 years in prison.
real_life_example: If you poison someone intending to cause serious harm, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Voluntarily Causing Hurt to Extort Confession or to Compel Restoration of Property - Section 330 IPC
text: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt, for the purpose of extorting from the sufferer or from any person interested in the sufferer any confession or any information which may lead to the detection of an offence or misconduct, or for the purpose of constraining the sufferer or any person interested in the sufferer to restore or to cause the restoration of any property or valuable security or to satisfy any claim or demand, or to give information which may lead to the restoration of any property or valuable security, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Causing hurt to force a confession or get back stolen property is punished with up to 7 years in prison.
real_life_example: If you beat someone to force them to confess to a crime or return stolen money, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Voluntarily Causing Grievous Hurt to Extort Confession or to Compel Restoration of Property - Section 331 IPC
text: Whoever voluntarily causes grievous hurt, for the purpose of extorting from the sufferer or from any person interested in the sufferer any confession or any information which may lead to the detection of an offence or misconduct, or for the purpose of constraining the sufferer or any person interested in the sufferer to restore or to cause the restoration of any property or valuable security or to satisfy any claim or demand, or to give information which may lead to the restoration of any property or valuable security, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Causing serious injury to force a confession or get back stolen property is punished with up to 10 years in prison.
real_life_example: If you torture someone severely to force them to confess or return stolen goods, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Voluntarily Causing Hurt to Deter Public Servant from His Duty - Section 332 IPC
text: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt to any person being a public servant in the discharge of his duty as such public servant, or with intent to prevent or deter that person from discharging his duty as such public servant, or in consequence of anything done or attempted to be done by that person in the lawful discharge of his duty as such public servant, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Hurting a public servant (like police, judge, government official) while they're doing their job is punished with up to 3 years in prison.
real_life_example: If you hit a police officer while they're arresting someone, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Voluntarily Causing Grievous Hurt to Deter Public Servant from His Duty - Section 333 IPC
text: Whoever voluntarily causes grievous hurt to any person being a public servant in the discharge of his duty as such public servant, or with intent to prevent or deter that person from discharging his duty as such public servant, or in consequence of anything done or attempted to be done by that person in the lawful discharge of his duty as such public servant, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Causing serious injury to a public servant while they're doing their job is punished with up to 10 years in prison.
real_life_example: If you seriously injure a police officer while they're on duty, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Voluntarily Causing Hurt on Provocation - Section 334 IPC
text: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt on grave and sudden provocation, if he neither intends nor knows himself to be likely to cause hurt to any person other than the person who gave the provocation, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: Causing hurt due to sudden provocation (without intending to hurt others) is punished with up to 1 month in prison or 500 rupees fine.
real_life_example: If someone insults you suddenly and you hit them in anger, you might get a lighter punishment of 1 month or 500 rupees fine.
punishment: Up to 1 month imprisonment and fine up to 500 rupees

title: Voluntarily Causing Grievous Hurt on Provocation - Section 335 IPC
text: Whoever voluntarily causes grievous hurt on grave and sudden provocation, if he neither intends nor knows himself to be likely to cause grievous hurt to any person other than the person who gave the provocation, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to four years, or with fine which may extend to two thousand rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: Causing serious injury due to sudden provocation (without intending to hurt others) is punished with up to 4 years in prison or 2000 rupees fine.
real_life_example: If someone provokes you suddenly and you cause serious injury in anger, you might get up to 4 years or 2000 rupees fine.
punishment: Up to 4 years imprisonment and fine up to 2000 rupees

title: Act Endangering Life or Personal Safety of Others - Section 336 IPC
text: Whoever does any act so rashly or negligently as to endanger human life or the personal safety of others, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to two hundred and fifty rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: Doing something carelessly that puts others' lives in danger is punished with up to 3 months in prison or 250 rupees fine.
real_life_example: If you drive recklessly and endanger other people's lives, you can be jailed for up to 3 months or fined 250 rupees.
punishment: Up to 3 months imprisonment and fine up to 250 rupees

title: Causing Hurt by Act Endangering Life or Personal Safety of Others - Section 337 IPC
text: Whoever causes hurt to any person by doing any act so rashly or negligently as to endanger human life or the personal safety of others, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: Causing hurt to someone by doing something carelessly that endangers lives is punished with up to 6 months in prison or 500 rupees fine.
real_life_example: If you drive carelessly and hit someone, causing them injury, you can be jailed for up to 6 months or fined 500 rupees.
punishment: Up to 6 months imprisonment and fine up to 500 rupees

title: Causing Grievous Hurt by Act Endangering Life or Personal Safety of Others - Section 338 IPC
text: Whoever causes grievous hurt to any person by doing any act so rashly or negligently as to endanger human life or the personal safety of others, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: Causing serious injury to someone by doing something carelessly that endangers lives is punished with up to 2 years in prison or 1000 rupees fine.
real_life_example: If you drive carelessly and cause someone serious injury, you can be jailed for up to 2 years or fined 1000 rupees.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine up to 1000 rupees

title: Wrongful Restraint - Section 339 IPC
text: Whoever voluntarily obstructs any person so as to prevent that person from proceeding in any direction in which that person has a right to proceed, is said wrongfully to restrain that person.
simplified_summary: Preventing someone from going where they have a right to go is called wrongful restraint.
real_life_example: If you block someone's path and prevent them from walking forward, you have wrongfully restrained them.
punishment: Up to 1 month imprisonment and fine up to 500 rupees

title: Wrongful Confinement - Section 340 IPC
text: Whoever wrongfully restrains any person in such a manner as to prevent that person from proceeding beyond certain circumscribing limits, is said 'wrongfully to confine' that person.
simplified_summary: Keeping someone within certain limits and preventing them from leaving is called wrongful confinement.
real_life_example: If you lock someone in a room and prevent them from leaving, you have wrongfully confined them.
punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment and fine up to 1000 rupees

title: Punishment for Wrongful Restraint - Section 341 IPC
text: Whoever wrongfully restrains any person shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: Wrongful restraint is punished with up to 1 month in prison or 500 rupees fine.
real_life_example: If you block someone's path and prevent them from moving, you can be jailed for up to 1 month or fined 500 rupees.
punishment: Up to 1 month imprisonment and fine up to 500 rupees

title: Punishment for Wrongful Confinement - Section 342 IPC
text: Whoever wrongfully confines any person shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: Wrongful confinement is punished with up to 1 year in prison or 1000 rupees fine.
real_life_example: If you lock someone up and prevent them from leaving, you can be jailed for up to 1 year or fined 1000 rupees.
punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment and fine up to 1000 rupees

title: Wrongful Confinement for Three or More Days - Section 343 IPC
text: Whoever wrongfully confines any person for three days or more, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Wrongfully confining someone for 3 or more days is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you lock someone up for 3 days or more, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Wrongful Confinement for Ten or More Days - Section 344 IPC
text: Whoever wrongfully confines any person for ten days or more, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Wrongfully confining someone for 10 or more days is punished with up to 3 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you lock someone up for 10 days or more, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Wrongful Confinement of Person for Whose Liberation Writ Has Been Issued - Section 345 IPC
text: Whoever keeps any person in wrongful confinement, knowing that a writ for the liberation of that person has been duly issued, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Keeping someone in wrongful confinement even after a court orders their release is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If a court orders someone's release but you keep them locked up anyway, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Wrongful Confinement in Secret - Section 346 IPC
text: Whoever wrongfully confines any person in such manner as to indicate an intention that the confinement of such person may not be known to any person interested in the person so confined, or to any public servant, or that the place of such confinement may not be known to or discovered by any such person or public servant as aforesaid, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, in addition to any other punishment to which he may be liable for such wrongful confinement.
simplified_summary: Wrongfully confining someone in secret (so others can't find them) is punished with up to 2 years in prison, in addition to other punishments.
real_life_example: If you lock someone up in a hidden place so their family can't find them, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment (in addition to other punishments)

title: Wrongful Confinement to Extort Property or to Constrain to Illegal Act - Section 347 IPC
text: Whoever wrongfully confines any person for the purpose of extorting from the person confined or from any person interested in the person confined any property or valuable security, or of constraining the person confined or any person interested in the person confined to do anything which is illegal or which may facilitate the commission of an offence, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Wrongfully confining someone to extort money or force them to do something illegal is punished with up to 3 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you lock someone up to force them to give you money or commit a crime, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Wrongful Confinement to Extort Confession or to Compel Restoration of Property - Section 348 IPC
text: Whoever wrongfully confines any person for the purpose of extorting from the person confined or from any person interested in the person confined any confession or any information which may lead to the detection of an offence or misconduct, or for the purpose of constraining the person confined or any person interested in the person confined to restore or to cause the restoration of any property or valuable security or to satisfy any claim or demand, or to give information which may lead to the restoration of any property or valuable security, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Wrongfully confining someone to force a confession or get back stolen property is punished with up to 3 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you lock someone up to force them to confess to a crime or return stolen goods, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Force - Section 349 IPC
text: A person is said to use force to another if he causes motion, change of motion, or cessation of motion to that other, or if he causes to any substance such motion or change of motion or cessation of motion as brings that substance into contact with any part of that other's body, or with anything which that other is wearing or carrying, or with anything so situated that such contact affects that other's sense of feeling: Provided that the person causing the motion, change of motion, or cessation of motion causes that motion, change of motion, or cessation of motion in one of the three ways hereinafter described: (1) By his own bodily power; (2) By disposing any substance in such a manner that the motion or change or cessation of motion takes place without any further act on his part or on the part of any other person; (3) By inducing any animal to move, to change its motion, or to cease to move.
simplified_summary: Force means causing any movement or change in movement to another person or their belongings, either directly or through objects or animals.
real_life_example: If you push someone, throw something at them, or make an animal attack them, you have used force against them.
punishment: Depends on the type of force used

title: Criminal Force - Section 350 IPC
text: Whoever intentionally uses force to any person, without that person's consent, in order to the committing of any offence, or intending by the use of such force to cause, or knowing it to be likely that by the use of such force he will cause injury, fear or annoyance to the person to whom the force is used, is said to use criminal force to that other.
simplified_summary: Using force against someone without their consent to commit a crime or cause injury, fear, or annoyance is called criminal force.
real_life_example: If you push someone without their permission to scare them or steal from them, you have used criminal force.
punishment: Up to 3 months imprisonment and fine up to 500 rupees

title: Assault - Section 351 IPC
text: Whoever makes any gesture, or any preparation intending or knowing it to be likely that such gesture or preparation will cause any person present to apprehend that he who makes that gesture or preparation is about to use criminal force to that person, is said to commit an assault.
simplified_summary: Making threatening gestures or preparations that make someone fear you will attack them is called assault.
real_life_example: If you raise your fist at someone in a threatening manner, making them fear you will hit them, you have committed assault.
punishment: Up to 3 months imprisonment and fine up to 500 rupees

title: Punishment for Assault or Criminal Force Otherwise Than on Grave Provocation - Section 352 IPC
text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person otherwise than on grave and sudden provocation given by that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: Assaulting or using criminal force against someone (except in response to serious provocation) is punished with up to 3 months in prison or 500 rupees fine.
real_life_example: If you hit someone without serious provocation, you can be jailed for up to 3 months or fined 500 rupees.
punishment: Up to 3 months imprisonment and fine up to 500 rupees

title: Assault or Criminal Force to Deter Public Servant from Discharge of His Duty - Section 353 IPC
text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person being a public servant in the execution of his duty as such public servant, or with intent to prevent or deter that person from discharging his duty as such public servant, or in consequence of anything done or attempted to be done by that person in the lawful discharge of his duty as such public servant, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Assaulting or using force against a public servant while they're doing their job is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you hit a police officer while they're arresting someone, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Assault or Criminal Force to Woman with Intent to Outrage Her Modesty - Section 354 IPC
text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any woman, intending to outrage or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby outrage her modesty, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Assaulting or using force against a woman to insult her modesty is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you touch a woman inappropriately or make unwanted physical contact, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Sexual Harassment and Punishment for Sexual Harassment - Section 354A IPC
text: A man committing any of the following acts: (i) physical contact and advances involving unwelcome and explicit sexual overtures; or (ii) a demand or request for sexual favours; or (iii) showing pornography against the will of a woman; or (iv) making sexually coloured remarks, shall be guilty of the offence of sexual harassment.
simplified_summary: Sexual harassment includes unwanted physical contact, sexual demands, showing pornography, or making sexual comments against a woman's will.
real_life_example: If you make sexual comments to a female colleague or show her inappropriate pictures, you can be charged with sexual harassment.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Assault or Use of Criminal Force to Woman with Intent to Disrobe - Section 354B IPC
text: Any man who assaults or uses criminal force to any woman or abets such act with the intention of disrobing or compelling her to be naked, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than three years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Forcing a woman to remove her clothes or making her naked against her will is punished with 3-7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you force a woman to remove her clothes against her will, you can be jailed for 3-7 years.
punishment: 3-7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Voyeurism - Section 354C IPC
text: Any man who watches, or captures the image of a woman engaging in a private act in circumstances where she would usually have the expectation of not being observed either by the perpetrator or by any other person at the behest of the perpetrator or disseminates such image shall be punished.
simplified_summary: Watching or recording a woman in private without her consent (voyeurism) is a serious crime.
real_life_example: If you secretly record a woman changing clothes or using the bathroom, you can be charged with voyeurism.
punishment: 1-3 years imprisonment and fine for first offence, 3-7 years for repeat offence

title: Stalking - Section 354D IPC
text: Any man who follows a woman and contacts, or attempts to contact such woman to foster personal interaction repeatedly despite a clear indication of disinterest by such woman; or monitors the use by a woman of the internet, email or any other form of electronic communication, commits the offence of stalking.
simplified_summary: Following a woman or repeatedly contacting her despite her clear disinterest, or monitoring her online activities is called stalking.
real_life_example: If you keep following a woman home or repeatedly call her after she asks you to stop, you can be charged with stalking.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine for first offence, up to 5 years for repeat offence

title: Assault or Criminal Force with Intent to Dishonour Person - Section 355 IPC
text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, intending thereby to dishonour that person, otherwise than on grave and sudden provocation given by that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Assaulting someone to insult or dishonour them (except in response to serious provocation) is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you slap someone in public to humiliate them, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Assault or Criminal Force in Attempt to Commit Theft of Property Carried by a Person - Section 356 IPC
text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, in attempting to commit theft of property which that person is then wearing or carrying, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Using force to steal something someone is wearing or carrying is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you snatch someone's phone or wallet from their hand using force, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Assault or Criminal Force in Attempt Wrongfully to Confine a Person - Section 357 IPC
text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person, in attempting wrongfully to confine that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: Using force to try to wrongfully confine someone is punished with up to 1 year in prison or 1000 rupees fine.
real_life_example: If you try to force someone into a room against their will, you can be jailed for up to 1 year.
punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment and fine up to 1000 rupees

title: Assault or Criminal Force on Grave Provocation - Section 358 IPC
text: Whoever assaults or uses criminal force to any person on grave and sudden provocation given by that person, shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term which may extend to one month, or with fine which may extend to two hundred rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: Assaulting someone in response to serious provocation is punished with up to 1 month in prison or 200 rupees fine.
real_life_example: If someone seriously provokes you and you hit them in response, you might get a lighter punishment of 1 month or 200 rupees fine.
punishment: Up to 1 month imprisonment and fine up to 200 rupees

title: Kidnapping - Section 359 IPC
text: Kidnapping is of two kinds: kidnapping from India, and kidnapping from lawful guardianship.
simplified_summary: Kidnapping has two types: taking someone out of India, or taking someone away from their legal guardian.
real_life_example: If you take a child away from their parents without permission, or force someone to leave the country, it's kidnapping.
punishment: Depends on type of kidnapping

title: Kidnapping from India - Section 360 IPC
text: Whoever conveys any person beyond the limits of India without the consent of that person, or of some person legally authorized to consent on behalf of that person, is said to kidnap that person from India.
simplified_summary: Taking someone out of India without their consent or their legal guardian's consent is kidnapping from India.
real_life_example: If you force someone to go to another country against their will, you have kidnapped them from India.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Kidnapping from Lawful Guardianship - Section 361 IPC
text: Whoever takes or entices any minor under sixteen years of age if a male, or under eighteen years of age if a female, or any person of unsound mind, out of the keeping of the lawful guardian of such minor or person of unsound mind, without the consent of such guardian, is said to kidnap such minor or person from lawful guardianship.
simplified_summary: Taking a minor (under 16 for boys, under 18 for girls) or mentally unsound person away from their legal guardian without consent is kidnapping.
real_life_example: If you take a 15-year-old boy or 17-year-old girl away from their parents without permission, it's kidnapping.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Abduction - Section 362 IPC
text: Whoever by force compels, or by any deceitful means induces, any person to go from any place, is said to abduct that person.
simplified_summary: Forcing or tricking someone to go somewhere against their will is called abduction.
real_life_example: If you trick someone into getting into your car by lying, or force them to come with you, it's abduction.
punishment: Depends on purpose of abduction

title: Punishment for Kidnapping - Section 363 IPC
text: Whoever kidnaps any person from India or from lawful guardianship, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Kidnapping is punished with up to 7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you kidnap someone, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Kidnapping or Maiming a Minor for Purposes of Begging - Section 363A IPC
text: Whoever kidnaps any minor or, not being the lawful guardian of a minor, obtains the custody of the minor, in order that such minor may be employed or used for the purposes of begging shall be punished.
simplified_summary: Kidnapping a child to use them for begging is a serious crime with severe punishment.
real_life_example: If you take a child away from their family to force them to beg on the streets, you can be charged with this crime.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Kidnapping or Abducting in Order to Murder - Section 364 IPC
text: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person in order that such person may be murdered or may be so disposed of as to be put in danger of being murdered, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Kidnapping someone to kill them or put them in danger of being killed is punished with life imprisonment or up to 10 years.
real_life_example: If you kidnap someone intending to kill them, you can be jailed for life or up to 10 years.
punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine

title: Kidnapping or Abducting with Intent Secretly and Wrongfully to Confine Person - Section 365 IPC
text: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person with intent to cause that person to be secretly and wrongfully confined, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Kidnapping someone to secretly confine them is punished with up to 7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you kidnap someone to lock them up in a hidden place, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Kidnapping, Abducting or Inducing Woman to Compel Her Marriage - Section 366 IPC
text: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any woman with intent that she may be compelled, or knowing it to be likely that she will be compelled, to marry any person against her will, or in order that she may be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse, or knowing it to be likely that she will be forced or seduced to illicit intercourse, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Kidnapping a woman to force her into marriage or sexual intercourse against her will is punished with up to 10 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you kidnap a woman to force her to marry someone she doesn't want to marry, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Procuration of Minor Girl - Section 366A IPC
text: Whoever, by any means whatsoever, induces any minor girl under the age of eighteen years to go from any place or to do any act with intent that such girl may be, or knowing that it is likely that such girl will be, forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person, shall be punished.
simplified_summary: Inducing a minor girl (under 18) to go somewhere or do something knowing she will be forced into sexual intercourse is a serious crime.
real_life_example: If you trick a 16-year-old girl into going somewhere knowing she will be forced into sexual activity, you can be charged with this crime.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Importation of Girl from Foreign Country - Section 366B IPC
text: Whoever imports into India from any country outside India any girl under the age of twenty-one years with intent that she may be, or knowing it to be likely that she will be, forced or seduced to illicit intercourse with another person, shall be punished.
simplified_summary: Bringing a girl under 21 from another country knowing she will be forced into sexual activity is a serious crime.
real_life_example: If you bring a 19-year-old girl from another country knowing she will be forced into prostitution, you can be charged with this crime.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Kidnapping or Abducting in Order to Subject Person to Grievous Hurt - Section 367 IPC
text: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any person in order that such person may be subjected, or may be so disposed of as to be put in danger of being subjected to grievous hurt, or slavery, or to the unnatural lust of any person, or knowing it to be likely that such person will be so subjected or disposed of, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Kidnapping someone to cause them serious injury, slavery, or sexual abuse is punished with up to 10 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you kidnap someone to torture them or force them into slavery, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Wrongfully Concealing or Keeping in Confinement Kidnapped or Abducted Person - Section 368 IPC
text: Whoever, knowing that any person has been kidnapped or has been abducted, wrongfully conceals or confines such person, shall be punished in the same manner as if he had kidnapped or abducted such person with the same intention or knowledge, or for the same purpose as that with or for which he conceals or detains such person.
simplified_summary: Hiding or confining someone you know has been kidnapped is punished the same as if you had kidnapped them yourself.
real_life_example: If you know someone has been kidnapped and you hide them in your house, you can be charged as if you kidnapped them yourself.
punishment: Same as kidnapping (up to 7 years imprisonment and fine)

title: Kidnapping or Abducting Child Under Ten Years with Intent to Steal from Its Person - Section 369 IPC
text: Whoever kidnaps or abducts any child under the age of ten years with the intention of taking dishonestly any moveable property from the person of such child, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Kidnapping a child under 10 to steal from them is punished with up to 7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you kidnap a 8-year-old child to steal their jewelry or money, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Buying or Disposing of Any Person as a Slave - Section 370 IPC
text: Whoever imports, exports, removes, buys, sells or disposes of any person as a slave, or accepts, receives or detains against his will any person as a slave, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Buying, selling, or treating someone as a slave is punished with up to 7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you buy or sell a person as a slave, or force someone to work as your slave, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Exploitation of Trafficked Person - Section 370A IPC
text: Whoever, knowingly or having reason to believe that a person has been trafficked, engages such person for sexual exploitation or forced labour, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than three years, but which may extend to five years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Using a trafficked person for sexual exploitation or forced labor is punished with 3-5 years rigorous imprisonment and fine.
real_life_example: If you know someone has been trafficked and you force them to work or engage in sexual activities, you can be jailed for 3-5 years.
punishment: 3-5 years rigorous imprisonment and fine

title: Habitual Dealing in Slaves - Section 371 IPC
text: Whoever habitually imports, exports, removes, buys, sells, traffics or deals in slaves, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term not exceeding ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Regularly dealing in slaves (human trafficking) is punished with life imprisonment or up to 10 years and fine.
real_life_example: If you regularly buy and sell people as slaves, you can be jailed for life or up to 10 years.
punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Selling Minors for Prostitution - Section 372 IPC
text: Whoever sells, lets to hire, or otherwise disposes of any person under the age of eighteen years with intent that such person shall at any age be employed or used for the purpose of prostitution or illicit intercourse with any person or for any unlawful and immoral purpose, shall be punished.
simplified_summary: Selling or hiring out a minor (under 18) for prostitution or sexual activities is a serious crime.
real_life_example: If you sell a 16-year-old girl to someone for prostitution, you can be charged with this serious crime.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Buying Minors for Prostitution - Section 373 IPC
text: Whoever buys, hires or otherwise obtains possession of any person under the age of eighteen years with intent that such person shall at any age be employed or used for the purpose of prostitution or illicit intercourse with any person or for any unlawful and immoral purpose, shall be punished.
simplified_summary: Buying or hiring a minor (under 18) for prostitution or sexual activities is a serious crime.
real_life_example: If you buy a 17-year-old boy or girl for sexual activities, you can be charged with this serious crime.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Unlawful Compulsory Labour - Section 374 IPC
text: Whoever unlawfully compels any person to labour against the will of that person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Forcing someone to work against their will is punished with up to 1 year in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you force someone to work for you without paying them or against their will, you can be jailed for up to 1 year.
punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment and fine

title: Rape - Section 375 IPC
text: A man is said to commit 'rape' if he: (a) penetrates his penis, to any extent, into the vagina, mouth, urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or (b) inserts, to any extent, any object or a part of the body, not being the penis, into the vagina, the urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or (c) manipulates any part of the body of a woman so as to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person; or (d) applies his mouth to the vagina, urethra or anus of a woman or makes her to do so with him or any other person, under the circumstances falling under any of the following seven descriptions.
simplified_summary: Rape includes various forms of sexual penetration without consent, including with objects or body parts other than penis.
real_life_example: If you force any form of sexual penetration on a woman without her consent, it is rape.
punishment: Imprisonment for not less than 7 years but which may extend to life imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Rape - Section 376 IPC
text: Whoever commits rape shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than seven years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Rape is punished with at least 7 years rigorous imprisonment, which may extend to life imprisonment, and fine.
real_life_example: If you are convicted of rape, you will be jailed for at least 7 years and possibly for life.
punishment: Not less than 7 years rigorous imprisonment, may extend to life imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Causing Death or Resulting in Persistent Vegetative State of Victim - Section 376A IPC
text: Whoever commits an offence punishable under sub-section (1) or sub-section (2) of section 376 and in the course of such commission inflicts an injury which causes the death of the person or causes the person to be in a persistent vegetative state, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, or with death.
simplified_summary: If rape causes the victim's death or puts them in a vegetative state, the punishment is at least 20 years imprisonment, life imprisonment, or death penalty.
real_life_example: If you rape someone and they die as a result, you can be sentenced to at least 20 years in prison or death penalty.
punishment: Not less than 20 years rigorous imprisonment, may extend to life imprisonment or death

title: Sexual Intercourse by Husband Upon His Wife During Separation - Section 376B IPC
text: Whoever has sexual intercourse with his own wife, who is living separately from him under a decree of separation or under any custom or usage without her consent, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Having sexual intercourse with your wife without her consent when you are legally separated is punishable with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you force sexual intercourse on your wife when you are legally separated and she doesn't consent, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Sexual Intercourse by a Person in Authority - Section 376C IPC
text: Whoever, being in a position of authority or in a fiduciary relationship; or a public servant; or a member of the management or staff of a jail, remand home or other place of custody; or being on the management or staff of a hospital, takes advantage of his position and commits sexual intercourse with a woman in such custody or receiving treatment, shall be punished.
simplified_summary: Using your position of authority to have sexual intercourse with a woman under your care or custody is a serious crime.
real_life_example: If you are a jail officer and force sexual intercourse on a female prisoner, you can be charged with this serious crime.
punishment: Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 5 years but which may extend to 10 years and fine

title: Gang Rape - Section 376D IPC
text: Where a woman is raped by one or more persons constituting a group or acting in furtherance of a common intention, each of those persons shall be deemed to have committed the offence of rape and shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to life imprisonment, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, and with fine.
simplified_summary: When a woman is raped by a group of people, each person in the group is punished with at least 20 years imprisonment, which may extend to life imprisonment, and fine.
real_life_example: If you are part of a group that rapes a woman, you will be jailed for at least 20 years and possibly for life.
punishment: Not less than 20 years rigorous imprisonment, may extend to life imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Repeat Offenders - Section 376E IPC
text: Whoever has been previously convicted of an offence punishable under section 376 or section 376A or section 376B or section 376C or section 376D and is subsequently convicted of an offence punishable under any of the said sections, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person's natural life, or with death.
simplified_summary: If you commit rape again after being previously convicted of rape, you can be sentenced to life imprisonment or death penalty.
real_life_example: If you are convicted of rape twice, you can be sentenced to life in prison or death penalty.
punishment: Life imprisonment or death

title: Unnatural Offences - Section 377 IPC
text: Whoever voluntarily has carnal intercourse against the order of nature with any man, woman or animal, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Having sexual intercourse against the order of nature (sodomy, bestiality) is punished with up to 10 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you have sexual intercourse with an animal or engage in sodomy, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Theft - Section 378 IPC
text: Whoever, intending to take dishonestly any moveable property out of the possession of any person without that person's consent, moves that property in order to such taking, is said to commit theft.
simplified_summary: Taking someone's movable property without their consent with dishonest intention is called theft.
real_life_example: If you take someone's phone, wallet, or car without their permission, it is theft.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Theft - Section 379 IPC
text: Whoever commits theft shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Theft is punished with up to 3 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you steal something, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Theft in Dwelling House - Section 380 IPC
text: Whoever commits theft in any building, tent or vessel, which building, tent or vessel is used as a human dwelling, or used for the custody of property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Theft from a house, tent, or vessel used as dwelling or for storing property is punished with up to 7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you steal something from someone's house, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Theft by Clerk or Servant of Property in Possession of Master - Section 381 IPC
text: Whoever, being a clerk or servant, or being employed in the capacity of a clerk or servant, commits theft in respect of any property in the possession of his master or employer, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: If you are a clerk or servant and steal from your master or employer, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
real_life_example: If you work as a servant and steal money from your employer's house, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Theft After Preparation Made for Causing Death, Hurt or Restraint - Section 382 IPC
text: Whoever commits theft, having made preparation for causing death, or hurt, or restraint, or fear of death, or of hurt, or of restraint, to any person, in order to the committing of the theft, or in order to the effecting of the escape after the committing of the theft, or in order to the retaining of property taken by the theft, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Theft with preparation to cause death, hurt, or restraint is punished with up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine.
real_life_example: If you prepare to hurt someone while stealing or to escape after stealing, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine

title: Extortion - Section 383 IPC
text: Whoever intentionally puts any person in fear of any injury to that person, or to any other, and thereby dishonestly induces the person so put in fear to deliver to any person any property or valuable security, or anything signed or sealed which may be converted into a valuable security, commits 'extortion'.
simplified_summary: Threatening someone with injury to force them to give you property or money is called extortion.
real_life_example: If you threaten to hurt someone unless they give you money, it is extortion.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Extortion - Section 384 IPC
text: Whoever commits extortion shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Extortion is punished with up to 3 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you extort money from someone, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Putting Person in Fear of Death or of Grievous Hurt in Order to Commit Extortion - Section 385 IPC
text: Whoever, in order to the committing of extortion, puts or attempts to put any person in fear of death or of grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Threatening someone with death or serious injury to extort money is punished with up to 7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you threaten to kill someone or cause serious injury to force them to give you money, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Extortion by Putting a Person in Fear of Death or Grievous Hurt - Section 386 IPC
text: Whoever commits extortion by putting any person in fear of death or of grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Extorting money by threatening death or serious injury is punished with up to 10 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you successfully extort money by threatening to kill someone or cause serious injury, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Putting Person in Fear of Death or of Grievous Hurt in Order to Commit Extortion - Section 387 IPC
