text: Whoever, in order to the committing of extortion, puts or attempts to put any person in fear of death or of grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Attempting to extort by threatening death or serious injury is punished with up to 7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you try to extort money by threatening to kill someone, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Extortion by Putting a Person in Fear of Death or Grievous Hurt - Section 388 IPC
text: Whoever commits extortion by putting any person in fear of death or of grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Successfully extorting by threatening death or serious injury is punished with up to 10 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you successfully extort money by threatening serious harm, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Putting Person in Fear of Death or of Grievous Hurt in Order to Commit Extortion - Section 389 IPC
text: Whoever, in order to the committing of extortion, puts or attempts to put any person in fear of death or of grievous hurt to that person or to any other, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Threatening death or serious injury to commit extortion is punished with up to 7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you threaten to kill someone to force them to give you money, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Robbery - Section 390 IPC
text: In all robbery there is either theft or extortion. When theft is robbery: Theft is 'robbery' if, in order to the committing of the theft, or in committing the theft, or in carrying away or attempting to carry away property obtained by the theft, the offender, for that end, voluntarily causes or attempts to cause to any person death or hurt or wrongful restraint, or fear of instant death or of instant hurt, or of instant wrongful restraint.
simplified_summary: Robbery is theft or extortion with violence or threat of violence. Theft becomes robbery when you use force or threat of force.
real_life_example: If you steal someone's wallet while threatening them with a knife, it becomes robbery instead of just theft.
punishment: Up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine

title: Dacoity - Section 391 IPC
text: When five or more persons conjointly commit or attempt to commit a robbery, or where the whole number of persons conjointly committing or attempting to commit a robbery, and persons present and aiding such commission or attempt, amount to five or more, every person so committing, attempting or aiding, is said to commit 'dacoity'.
simplified_summary: When 5 or more people together commit robbery, it is called dacoity.
real_life_example: If 5 or more people together rob a bank or a person, it is dacoity.
punishment: Up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Robbery - Section 392 IPC
text: Whoever commits robbery shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine; and, if the robbery be committed on the highway between sunset and sunrise, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to fourteen years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Robbery is punished with up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine. If committed on highway at night, punishment is up to 14 years.
real_life_example: If you rob someone, you can be jailed for up to 10 years. If you rob on a highway at night, you can be jailed for up to 14 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine (14 years if on highway at night)

title: Attempt to Commit Robbery - Section 393 IPC
text: Whoever attempts to commit robbery shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Attempting to commit robbery is punished with up to 7 years rigorous imprisonment and fine.
real_life_example: If you try to rob someone but fail, you can still be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years rigorous imprisonment and fine

title: Voluntarily Causing Hurt in Committing Robbery - Section 394 IPC
text: If any person, in committing or in attempting to commit robbery, voluntarily causes hurt, such person, and any other person jointly concerned in committing or attempting to commit such robbery, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: If you cause hurt while committing robbery, you and your accomplices can be jailed for life or up to 10 years.
real_life_example: If you hurt someone while robbing them, you can be jailed for life or up to 10 years.
punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Dacoity - Section 395 IPC
text: Whoever commits dacoity shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Dacoity is punished with life imprisonment or up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine.
real_life_example: If you are part of a group of 5 or more people that commits robbery, you can be jailed for life or up to 10 years.
punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine

title: Dacoity with Murder - Section 396 IPC
text: If any one of five or more persons, who are conjointly committing dacoity, commits murder in so committing dacoity, every one of those persons shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: If someone in a dacoity group commits murder, all members of the group can be sentenced to death, life imprisonment, or up to 10 years.
real_life_example: If your group of 5 people commits dacoity and one of you kills someone, all of you can be sentenced to death or life in prison.
punishment: Death, life imprisonment, or up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine

title: Robbery or Dacoity with Attempt to Cause Death or Grievous Hurt - Section 397 IPC
text: If, at the time of committing robbery or dacoity, the offender uses any deadly weapon, or causes grievous hurt to any person, or attempts to cause death or grievous hurt to any person, the imprisonment with which such offender shall be punished shall not be less than seven years.
simplified_summary: If you use a deadly weapon or cause serious injury during robbery or dacoity, you must be jailed for at least 7 years.
real_life_example: If you rob someone with a knife or cause serious injury during robbery, you must be jailed for at least 7 years.
punishment: Not less than 7 years imprisonment

title: Attempt to Commit Robbery or Dacoity When Armed with Deadly Weapon - Section 398 IPC
text: If, at the time of attempting to commit robbery or dacoity, the offender is armed with any deadly weapon, the imprisonment with which such offender shall be punished shall not be less than seven years.
simplified_summary: If you attempt robbery or dacoity while armed with a deadly weapon, you must be jailed for at least 7 years.
real_life_example: If you try to rob someone while carrying a knife or gun, you must be jailed for at least 7 years.
punishment: Not less than 7 years imprisonment

title: Making Preparation to Commit Dacoity - Section 399 IPC
text: Whoever makes any preparation for committing dacoity, shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Making preparations to commit dacoity is punished with up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine.
real_life_example: If you plan and prepare to commit dacoity with a group, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine

title: Belonging to Gang of Dacoits - Section 400 IPC
text: Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall have been habitually associated with any other or others for the purpose of committing robbery or child-stealing by means of or accompanied by murder, is a thug.
simplified_summary: Being part of a gang that regularly commits robbery or child-stealing with murder is a serious crime.
real_life_example: If you regularly work with a group that robs people and sometimes kills them, you can be charged with being a thug.
punishment: Imprisonment for life and fine

title: Punishment for Belonging to Gang of Dacoits - Section 401 IPC
text: Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall have been habitually associated with any other or others for the purpose of committing robbery or child-stealing by means of or accompanied by murder, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Being part of a gang that regularly commits robbery or child-stealing with murder is punished with life imprisonment and fine.
real_life_example: If you are part of a gang that regularly robs and kills people, you will spend the rest of your life in prison.
punishment: Imprisonment for life and fine

title: Assembling for Purpose of Committing Dacoity - Section 402 IPC
text: Whoever, at any time after the passing of this Act, shall have been habitually associated with any other or others for the purpose of committing robbery or child-stealing by means of or accompanied by murder, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Gathering with others to plan or commit dacoity is a serious crime.
real_life_example: If you meet with a group of people to plan a robbery, you can be charged with this crime.
punishment: Up to 7 years rigorous imprisonment and fine

title: Dishonest Misappropriation of Property - Section 403 IPC
text: Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use any movable property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Using someone else's movable property for your own benefit without their permission is criminal misappropriation.
real_life_example: If you find someone's lost wallet and use their money instead of returning it, it's criminal misappropriation.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Dishonest Misappropriation of Property Possessed by Deceased Person at Time of His Death - Section 404 IPC
text: Whoever dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use any movable property, knowing that it was in the possession of a deceased person at the time of that person's death, and has not since been in the possession of any person legally entitled to such possession, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Taking property from a dead person without legal right is criminal misappropriation, punished more severely.
real_life_example: If you take jewelry or money from someone who just died without being their legal heir, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Criminal Breach of Trust - Section 405 IPC
text: Whoever, being in any manner entrusted with property, or with any dominion over property, dishonestly misappropriates or converts to his own use that property, or dishonestly uses or disposes of that property in violation of any direction of law prescribing the mode in which such trust is to be discharged, or of any legal contract, express or implied, which he has made touching the discharge of such trust, or wilfully suffers any other person so to do, commits 'criminal breach of trust'.
simplified_summary: If someone trusts you with their property and you use it dishonestly for your own benefit, it's criminal breach of trust.
real_life_example: If you are given money to buy something for someone but you use it for yourself instead, it's criminal breach of trust.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Criminal Breach of Trust - Section 406 IPC
text: Whoever commits criminal breach of trust shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Criminal breach of trust is punished with up to 3 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you commit criminal breach of trust, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Criminal Breach of Trust by Carrier - Section 407 IPC
text: Whoever, being entrusted with property as a carrier, wharfinger or warehouse-keeper, commits criminal breach of trust in respect of such property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: If you are a carrier, wharfinger, or warehouse-keeper and commit breach of trust with entrusted property, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
real_life_example: If you run a transport company and steal goods entrusted to you for delivery, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Criminal Breach of Trust by Clerk or Servant - Section 408 IPC
text: Whoever, being a clerk or servant, or employed as a clerk or servant, and being in any manner entrusted in such capacity with property, or with any dominion over property, commits criminal breach of trust in respect of that property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: If you are a clerk or servant and commit breach of trust with property entrusted to you, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
real_life_example: If you work as an office clerk and steal money from your employer's safe, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Criminal Breach of Trust by Public Servant - Section 409 IPC
text: Whoever, being in any manner entrusted with property, or with any dominion over property in his capacity of a public servant, commits criminal breach of trust in respect of that property, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: If you are a public servant and commit breach of trust with entrusted property, you can be jailed for life or up to 10 years.
real_life_example: If you are a government officer and steal public money entrusted to you, you can be jailed for life or up to 10 years.
punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Stolen Property - Section 410 IPC
text: Property, the possession whereof has been transferred by theft, or by extortion, or by robbery, and property which has been criminally misappropriated or in respect of which criminal breach of trust has been committed, is designated as 'stolen property'.
simplified_summary: Property obtained through theft, extortion, robbery, misappropriation, or breach of trust is called stolen property.
real_life_example: If someone steals your phone and sells it to another person, that phone becomes stolen property.
punishment: Depends on the offence involving stolen property

title: Dishonestly Receiving Stolen Property - Section 411 IPC
text: Whoever dishonestly receives or retains any stolen property, knowing or having reason to believe the same to be stolen property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Receiving or keeping stolen property knowing it's stolen is a crime punishable with up to 3 years in prison.
real_life_example: If you buy a phone knowing it was stolen, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Dishonestly Receiving Property Stolen in Commission of Dacoity - Section 412 IPC
text: Whoever dishonestly receives or retains any stolen property, the possession whereof he knows or has reason to believe to have been transferred by the commission of dacoity, or dishonestly receives from a person whom he knows or has reason to believe to belong or to have belonged to a gang of dacoits, property which he knows or has reason to believe to have been stolen, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with rigorous imprisonment for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Receiving property stolen during dacoity or from dacoits is punished with life imprisonment or up to 10 years.
real_life_example: If you receive property knowing it was stolen during a dacoity, you can be jailed for life or up to 10 years.
punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years rigorous imprisonment and fine

title: Habitually Dealing in Stolen Property - Section 413 IPC
text: Whoever habitually receives or deals in property which he knows or has reason to believe to be stolen property, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Regularly dealing in stolen property is punished with life imprisonment or up to 10 years.
real_life_example: If you regularly buy and sell stolen goods, you can be jailed for life or up to 10 years.
punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Assisting in Concealment of Stolen Property - Section 414 IPC
text: Whoever voluntarily assists in concealing or disposing of or making away with property which he knows or has reason to believe to be stolen property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Helping to hide or dispose of stolen property is punished with up to 3 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you help someone hide stolen goods, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Cheating - Section 415 IPC
text: Whoever, by deceiving any person, fraudulently or dishonestly induces the person so deceived to deliver any property to any person, or to consent that any person shall retain any property, or intentionally induces the person so deceived to do or omit to do anything which he would not do or omit if he were not so deceived, and which act or omission causes or is likely to cause damage or harm to that person in body, mind, reputation or property, is said to 'cheat'.
simplified_summary: Cheating means deceiving someone to get property from them or make them do something that harms them.
real_life_example: If you lie to someone to get their money or make them sign a harmful contract, it's cheating.
punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment and fine

title: Cheating by Personation - Section 416 IPC
text: A person is said to 'cheat by personation' if he cheats by pretending to be some other person, or by knowingly substituting one person for another, or representing that he or any other person is a person other than he or such other person really is.
simplified_summary: Cheating by pretending to be someone else or substituting one person for another is called cheating by personation.
real_life_example: If you pretend to be someone else to get their benefits or make them sign documents, it's cheating by personation.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Cheating - Section 417 IPC
text: Whoever cheats shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Cheating is punished with up to 1 year in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you cheat someone, you can be jailed for up to 1 year.
punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment and fine

title: Cheating with Knowledge that Wrongful Loss May Ensue to Person Whose Interest Offender is Bound to Protect - Section 418 IPC
text: Whoever cheats with the knowledge that he is likely thereby to cause wrongful loss to a person whose interest in the transaction to which the cheating relates, he was bound, either by law, or by a legal contract, to protect, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Cheating someone whose interests you are legally bound to protect is punished with up to 3 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you are a lawyer and cheat your client, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Cheating by Personation - Section 419 IPC
text: Whoever cheats by personation shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Cheating by personation is punished with up to 3 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you cheat by pretending to be someone else, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Cheating and Dishonestly Inducing Delivery of Property - Section 420 IPC
text: Whoever cheats and thereby dishonestly induces the person deceived to deliver any property to any person, or to make, alter or destroy the whole or any part of a valuable security, or anything which is signed or sealed, and which is capable of being converted into a valuable security, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Cheating to get property or valuable documents is punished with up to 7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you cheat someone to get their money or property, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Dishonest or Fraudulent Removal or Concealment of Property - Section 421 IPC
text: Whoever dishonestly or fraudulently removes, conceals, or delivers to any person, or transfers or causes to be transferred to any person, without adequate consideration, any property, intending thereby to prevent, or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby prevent, the distribution of that property according to law among his creditors or creditors of any other person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Hiding or transferring property to avoid paying creditors is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you hide your property to avoid paying your debts, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Dishonestly or Fraudulently Preventing Debt Being Available for Creditors - Section 422 IPC
text: Whoever dishonestly or fraudulently prevents any debt or demand due to himself or to any other person from being made available according to law for payment of his debts or the debts of such other person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Preventing debts from being available to pay creditors is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you prevent money owed to you from being used to pay your debts, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Dishonest or Fraudulent Execution of Deed of Transfer Containing False Statement of Consideration - Section 423 IPC
text: Whoever dishonestly or fraudulently signs, executes or becomes a party to any deed or instrument which purports to transfer or subject to any charge any property, or any interest therein, and which contains any false statement relating to the consideration for such transfer or charge, or to the person or persons for whose use or benefit it is really intended to operate, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Making false statements in property transfer documents is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you lie about the price or purpose in a property sale document, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Dishonest or Fraudulent Removal or Concealment of Property - Section 424 IPC
text: Whoever dishonestly or fraudulently conceals or removes any property of himself or any other person, or dishonestly or fraudulently assists in the concealment or removal thereof, or dishonestly releases any demand or claim to which he is entitled, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Hiding or removing property to avoid legal obligations is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you hide your car to avoid it being seized for debts, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief - Section 425 IPC
text: Whoever with intent to cause, or knowing that he is likely to cause, wrongful loss or damage to the public or to any person, causes the destruction of any property, or any such change in any property or in the situation thereof as destroys or diminishes its value or utility, or affects it injuriously, commits 'mischief'.
simplified_summary: Intentionally damaging or destroying someone's property is called mischief.
real_life_example: If you break someone's window or damage their car intentionally, it's mischief.
punishment: Up to 3 months imprisonment and fine up to 500 rupees

title: Punishment for Mischief - Section 426 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Mischief is punished with up to 3 months in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you damage someone's property, you can be jailed for up to 3 months.
punishment: Up to 3 months imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief Causing Damage to the Amount of Fifty Rupees - Section 427 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief and thereby causes loss or damage to the amount of fifty rupees or upwards, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Mischief causing damage worth 50 rupees or more is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you damage someone's property worth 100 rupees, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief by Killing or Maiming Animal - Section 428 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming or rendering useless any animal of the value of ten rupees or upwards, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Killing, poisoning, or injuring an animal worth 10 rupees or more is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you poison someone's pet dog or cow, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief by Killing or Maiming Cattle - Section 429 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief by killing, poisoning, maiming or rendering useless any elephant, camel, horse, mule, buffalo, bull, cow or ox, whatever may be the value thereof, or any other animal of the value of fifty rupees or upwards, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Killing or injuring cattle or valuable animals is punished with up to 5 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you kill someone's cow or horse, you can be jailed for up to 5 years.
punishment: Up to 5 years imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief by Injury to Works of Irrigation - Section 430 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief by doing any act which causes, or which he knows to be likely to cause, a diminution of the supply of water for agricultural purposes, or for food or drink for human beings or for animals which are property, or for cleanliness or for carrying on any manufacture, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Damaging irrigation works or water supply is punished with up to 5 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you damage a canal or water tank that supplies water for farming, you can be jailed for up to 5 years.
punishment: Up to 5 years imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief by Injury to Public Road, Bridge, River or Channel - Section 431 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief by doing any act which renders or which he knows to be likely to render any public road, bridge, navigable river or navigable channel, natural or artificial, impassable or less safe for travelling or conveying property, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Damaging public roads, bridges, or waterways is punished with up to 5 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you damage a public bridge or road making it unsafe, you can be jailed for up to 5 years.
punishment: Up to 5 years imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief by Causing Inundation or Obstruction to Public Drain - Section 432 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief by doing any act which causes, or which he knows to be likely to cause, an inundation or an obstruction to any public drainage carried on by the public or by any municipal body, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Causing flooding or blocking public drainage is punished with up to 5 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you block a public drain causing flooding, you can be jailed for up to 5 years.
punishment: Up to 5 years imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief by Destroying, Moving or Rendering Less Useful a Lighthouse or Sea-Mark - Section 433 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief by destroying or moving any lighthouse or other light used as a sea-mark, or any sea-mark or buoy or other thing placed as a guide for navigators, or by any act which renders any such lighthouse, sea-mark, buoy or other thing less useful as a guide for navigators, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Damaging lighthouses or sea-marks is punished with up to 5 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you damage a lighthouse or sea buoy, you can be jailed for up to 5 years.
punishment: Up to 5 years imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief by Destroying or Moving, etc., a Land-Mark Fixed by Public Authority - Section 434 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief by destroying or moving any land-mark fixed by the authority of a public servant, or by any act which renders such land-mark less useful as such, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Damaging or moving land-marks fixed by public authority is punished with up to 1 year in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you remove or damage a boundary stone placed by government, you can be jailed for up to 1 year.
punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief by Fire or Explosive Substance - Section 435 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief by fire or any explosive substance, intending to cause, or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby cause, damage to any property to the amount of one hundred rupees or upwards, or any property which is used for the purpose of Government or any local authority, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Using fire or explosives to damage property worth 100 rupees or more, or government property, is punished with up to 7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you set fire to someone's house or government building, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief by Fire or Explosive Substance with Intent to Destroy House - Section 436 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief by fire or any explosive substance, intending to cause, or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby cause, the destruction of any building which is ordinarily used as a place of worship or as a human dwelling or as a place for the custody of property, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Using fire or explosives to destroy places of worship, houses, or property storage is punished with life imprisonment or up to 10 years.
real_life_example: If you burn down a temple, mosque, or someone's house, you can be jailed for life or up to 10 years.
punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief with Intent to Destroy or Make Unsafe a Decked Vessel - Section 437 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief to any decked vessel or any vessel of a burden of twenty tons or upwards, intending to destroy or render unsafe such vessel, or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby destroy or render unsafe such vessel, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Damaging a ship or large vessel to destroy or make it unsafe is punished with up to 10 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you damage a ship to make it sink or unsafe, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for the Mischief Described in Section 437 - Section 438 IPC
text: Whoever commits, or attempts to commit, by fire or any explosive substance, such mischief as is described in the last preceding section, shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Using fire or explosives to damage a ship is punished with life imprisonment or up to 10 years.
real_life_example: If you use explosives to damage a ship, you can be jailed for life or up to 10 years.
punishment: Life imprisonment or up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Intentionally Running Vessel Aground or Ashore - Section 439 IPC
text: Whoever intentionally runs any vessel aground or ashore, intending to commit theft of any property contained therein or to dishonestly misappropriate any such property, or with intent to cause wrongful loss to any person, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Intentionally running a ship aground to steal from it is punished with up to 10 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you intentionally run a ship aground to steal cargo, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Mischief Committed After Preparation Made for Causing Death or Hurt - Section 440 IPC
text: Whoever commits mischief, having made preparation for causing death or hurt to any person, or for causing wrongful restraint, or fear of death or of hurt to any person, or of wrongful restraint, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both.
simplified_summary: Committing mischief with preparation to cause death, hurt, or fear is punished with up to 5 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you prepare to hurt someone while damaging their property, you can be jailed for up to 5 years.
punishment: Up to 5 years imprisonment and fine

title: Criminal Trespass - Section 441 IPC
text: Whoever enters into or upon property in the possession of another with intent to commit an offence or to intimidate, insult or annoy any person in possession of such property, or having lawfully entered into or upon such property, unlawfully remains there with intent thereby to intimidate, insult or annoy any such person, or with intent to commit an offence, is said to commit 'criminal trespass'.
simplified_summary: Entering someone's property without permission to commit a crime or annoy them is called criminal trespass.
real_life_example: If you enter someone's house without permission to steal or annoy them, it's criminal trespass.
punishment: Up to 3 months imprisonment and fine up to 500 rupees

title: House-Trespass - Section 442 IPC
text: Whoever commits criminal trespass by entering into or remaining in any building, tent or vessel used as a human dwelling, or any building used as a place for worship, or as a place for the custody of property, is said to commit 'house-trespass'.
simplified_summary: Criminal trespass into a house, tent, vessel, place of worship, or property storage is called house-trespass.
real_life_example: If you enter someone's house without permission, it's house-trespass.
punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment and fine up to 1000 rupees

title: Lurking House-Trespass - Section 443 IPC
text: Whoever commits house-trespass having taken precautions to conceal such house-trespass from some person who has a right to exclude or eject the trespasser from the building, tent or vessel which is the subject of the trespass, is said to commit 'lurking house-trespass'.
simplified_summary: House-trespass while hiding to avoid being seen is called lurking house-trespass.
real_life_example: If you sneak into someone's house at night to avoid being seen, it's lurking house-trespass.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Lurking House-Trespass by Night - Section 444 IPC
text: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass after sunset and before sunrise, is said to commit 'lurking house-trespass by night'.
simplified_summary: Lurking house-trespass at night (between sunset and sunrise) is a more serious crime.
real_life_example: If you sneak into someone's house at night, it's lurking house-trespass by night.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: House-Breaking - Section 445 IPC
text: A person is said to commit 'house-breaking' who commits house-trespass if he effects his entrance into the house or any part of it in any of the six ways hereinafter described; or if, being in the house or any part of it for the purpose of committing an offence, or having committed an offence therein, he quits the house or any part of it in any of such six ways.
simplified_summary: House-trespass by entering or leaving through doors, windows, or other openings is called house-breaking.
real_life_example: If you break into someone's house through a window or door, it's house-breaking.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: House-Breaking by Night - Section 446 IPC
text: Whoever commits house-breaking after sunset and before sunrise, is said to commit 'house-breaking by night'.
simplified_summary: House-breaking at night (between sunset and sunrise) is a more serious crime.
real_life_example: If you break into someone's house at night, it's house-breaking by night.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Criminal Trespass - Section 447 IPC
text: Whoever commits criminal trespass shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three months, or with fine which may extend to five hundred rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: Criminal trespass is punished with up to 3 months in prison or 500 rupees fine.
real_life_example: If you enter someone's property without permission, you can be jailed for up to 3 months or fined 500 rupees.
punishment: Up to 3 months imprisonment and fine up to 500 rupees

title: Punishment for House-Trespass - Section 448 IPC
text: Whoever commits house-trespass shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.
simplified_summary: House-trespass is punished with up to 1 year in prison or 1000 rupees fine.
real_life_example: If you enter someone's house without permission, you can be jailed for up to 1 year or fined 1000 rupees.
punishment: Up to 1 year imprisonment and fine up to 1000 rupees

title: Punishment for Lurking House-Trespass - Section 449 IPC
text: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Lurking house-trespass is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you sneak into someone's house to avoid being seen, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Lurking House-Trespass by Night - Section 450 IPC
text: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass by night shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: Lurking house-trespass at night is punished with up to 3 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you sneak into someone's house at night, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for House-Breaking - Section 451 IPC
text: Whoever commits house-breaking shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to two years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: House-breaking is punished with up to 2 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you break into someone's house, you can be jailed for up to 2 years.
punishment: Up to 2 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for House-Breaking by Night - Section 452 IPC
text: Whoever commits house-breaking by night shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: House-breaking at night is punished with up to 3 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you break into someone's house at night, you can be jailed for up to 3 years.
punishment: Up to 3 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Lurking House-Trespass or House-Breaking After Preparation for Hurt, Assault or Wrongful Restraint - Section 453 IPC
text: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass or house-breaking, having made preparation for causing hurt to any person or for assaulting any person, or for wrongfully restraining any person, or for putting any person in fear of death or of hurt, or of wrongful restraint, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: House-trespass or house-breaking with preparation to hurt, assault, or restrain someone is punished with up to 7 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you break into someone's house with a weapon to hurt them, you can be jailed for up to 7 years.
punishment: Up to 7 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Lurking House-Trespass or House-Breaking by Night After Preparation for Hurt, Assault or Wrongful Restraint - Section 454 IPC
text: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass by night or house-breaking by night, having made preparation for causing hurt to any person or for assaulting any person, or for wrongfully restraining any person, or for putting any person in fear of death or of hurt, or of wrongful restraint, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to fine.
simplified_summary: House-trespass or house-breaking at night with preparation to hurt someone is punished with up to 10 years in prison and fine.
real_life_example: If you break into someone's house at night with a weapon to hurt them, you can be jailed for up to 10 years.
punishment: Up to 10 years imprisonment and fine

title: Punishment for Lurking House-Trespass or House-Breaking After Preparation for Hurt, Assault or Wrongful Restraint - Section 455 IPC
text: Whoever commits lurking house-trespass or house-breaking, having made preparation for causing hurt to any person or for assaulting any person, or for wrongfully restraining any person, or for putting any person in fear of death or of hurt, or of wrongful restraint, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.
